results.title: The Family: an approach to peace
results.brief_description: Shows that the only way to peace is in the understanding of other peoples, and contrasts the popular conception of foreign lands with life as it actually is around the globe. Through scenes of everyday family life everywhere, describes the similarity of the fears and aspirations of all people.

results.title: The Family that dwelt apart
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Robert Verrall, Wolf Koenig and Yvon Mallette
results.brief_description: Cartoon animation of a story by E.B. White, first published in the New Yorker magazine in 1937. This is a tall Yankee tale about a family of seven fisherfolk who are living quite happily as the sole inhabitants of a small island in Barnetuck Bay until word somehow gets to the mainland that they are in distress. What happens when rescue attempts are launched makes an amusing story, illustrated with wit and verve by the film animation. Narrated by E.B. White. Also available on DVD [319319].
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, Robert Verrall, Wolf Koenig and Yvon Mallette

results.title: The Family prince
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Jeannine Locke
results.brief_description: A candid look at the relevance and romance of the British monarchy from Prince Charles, Prince of Wales. Bridging the Prince’s frank, on-camera comments, the narrative script is combined with historical film footage to study the evolution of Crown and Commonwealth in modern times and to look at Charles’ younger years.

results.title: The Family of man. Part 3. Weddings (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Part three of the series, “The Family of Man” which sets out to compare family life in five different locations around the world. A comparison of weddings, the differences and similarities these rituals have in different societies are studied. There is also an investigation into some of the mysteries surrounding weddings in England - what the ring, veil, bouquet and wedding cake signify. By looking at weddings in other countries it is possible to make some shrewd guesses.

results.title:
The Family Law
script from season one, episode one, 2016
results.brief_description: Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a unique perspective on what it means to be Australian today.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Australia → 11. Screen Australia Showcase → MA-11-C01

results.media_note: Sorry, we aren't able to make images or video for this item available to the public online.

results.title: The Family Law exhibition footage
results.brief_description: The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. This artwork examines how representations of Australian landscapes have evolved from being dominated by the Outback to the suburbs and cities.
results.description:
Fourteen-year-old Benjamin Law is desperate to win his school’s talent show. Not only must he chart a course to high-school stardom, but he also needs to navigate all the issues of Australian adolescence: embarrassing parents, bickering siblings, school bullies, best friends and his own sexuality.

Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book of the same name, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a uniquely Asian Australian perspective on what it means to be Australian today.

results.title: The Family album
results.creator_credit: Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute and David Hopwood
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Developing image”.
Highlights the most frequent subject of photographers past and present, the family portrait. Provides a history of family portraiture, including daguerreotypes and wet-plate photography, as well as the development of Kodak roll-film cameras. Includes interviews with leading contemporary photographers who specialise in family portraiture.

results.title: The Family
results.creator_credit: United States. Army and Herbert Kerkow
results.brief_description: Family life as lived by a father, mother, two children and a grandmother is depicted. They are not in affluent circumstances and conflicts arise because the father wants to repair the house, mother wants a sewing machine, and the daughter a ball dress. They get together and talk out their problems; by so doing they strengthen the bonds of family life and create a sense of security among themselves.
results.description: Family life as lived by a father, mother, two children and a grandmother is depicted. results.title: The Falls
results.brief_description: A film which obsessively seeks to construct a self-sufficient world complete with a multiplicity of exotic languages and ornithological references. Ninety-two improbable surnames all with the prefix FALL have been randomly picked out as a block from the nineteen million names in the Standard directory of the Violent Unknown Event (VUE). Part 1 comprises 45 case histories (from FALLA to FALLBUTUS) presented through commentary, interview or enactment. Part 2 comprises 47 case histories (from FALLCAS to FALLWASTE) presented through commentary, interview or enactment. Director, writer, editor, Peter Greenaway ; music, Michael Nyman ; photography, Mike Coles, John Rosenberg.

results.title: The Fallout atom
results.creator_credit: Columbia Broadcasting System, Michael Sklar and Harold Mayer
results.brief_description: An examination of the scientific facts of human radiation filmed at the Argonne National Laboratory of the AEC in Lemont, Ill. Dr John E. Rose attempts to find out how much radioactive material the human body possesses naturally, how much we have been exposed to as a result of nuclear bomb tests, and the effects of radiation on health and life. Shows the tests of two groups of human guinea pigs; one group - radium dial painters who literally ate radium 30 years ago, and another group whose everyday drinking water has a higher-than-average percentage of radium.
